title: Former Socialist figure emerges as serious contender for French PM
summary: Following consultations led by Emmanuel Macron, former prime minister and interior minister Bernard Cazeneuve seems to be the only candidate without a majority against him in the Assemblée Nationale.

title: Environmental transition lost in political uncertainty
summary: While action on climate change is urgently needed, large parts of environmental policy are currently at a standstill. The sector awaits a new, more ambitious budget and strategic guidelines, whose publication has been repeatedly pushed back.

title: Trump moves to contain fallout of abortion, IVF backlash
summary: The former president has been under fire from conservatives over an announcement that in a second term he would ensure free in vitro fertilization – an expensive fertility procedure that many in the anti-abortion movement want to see curbed.

title: Macron hopes to break Belgrade's ties to Moscow with fighter jets sale
summary: Twelve aircraft are scheduled for delivery between 2028 and 2029. The French president praised a 'strategic change' likely to bring Serbia closer to the European Union.

title: Judge orders suspension of X social media site in Brazil as owner Elon Musk fires back: 'Pseudo-judge'
summary: Musk has been locked in a months-long feud with the judge, Alexandre de Moraes, who is leading a battle against disinformation in South America's largest nation.

title: Pro-Ukrainian Russian rebels kept out of Kursk offensive
summary: The Freedom of Russia and Russian Volunteer Corps units, which were excluded from Ukrainian military operations on Russian territory, hope to play a role in the future against Putin's regime.

title: Zelensky dismisses Ukraine air force commander after F-16 crash
summary: The Ukrainian president fired the air force commander on Friday after an F-16 warplane received from Western partners crashed during a Russian bombardment.

title: Mapping the Ukrainian army's incursion into Russia
summary: After entering Russia on August 6, Ukrainian troops now hold several hundred square kilometers of Russian territory in the Kursk region.

title: In West Africa, hairdressers are on the front line, helping clients with mental health problems
summary: Over 150 hairdressers in Togo, Cameroon and Côte d'Ivoire have benefited from a short educational course set up by the NGO Bluemind Foundation. The aim is to become 'the first link in the care chain' in a region where therapists are sorely lacking.

title: How Spain's largest dolmen was built nearly six thousand years ago
summary: Spanish researchers have analyzed the techniques used to build this complex megalith at Menga, whose heaviest stone weighs 150 tons.

title: Venezuela hit by nationwide power outage, Maduro blames 'criminal attack'
summary: President Nicolas Maduro's government has accused the United States and the political opposition of orchestrating the power failures, attributing the outages to unproven conspiracies to overthrow him. Opposition leaders and experts, however, blame corruption and a lack of investment and expertise for the outages.

title: Israeli air strike on Gaza kills four in aid convoy, says US-based aid group
summary: Anera claims an Israeli air strike targeted a lead vehicle in its aid convoy, killing four non-staff community members, while the Israeli military asserts the strike was aimed at armed assailants.

title: Milei's government undermines Argentina's remembrance policy
summary: MPs from Javier Milei's ruling party are now visiting a prison to visit people convicted of crimes against humanity. This comes after public bodies responsible for revealing atrocities committed during the dictatorship were dismantled.

title: The Paris Paralympics, another battleground for two Ukrainian soldiers
summary: For the duration of the Paris Games, Major Dmytro Melnyk and veteran Yevhenii Korinets are serving their country far from the noise of war, as members of the national sitting volleyball team. They play their first match against Iran on August 30.

title: New European Commission falls far short of von der Leyen's hoped-for gender parity
summary: Member states have until Friday to propose their candidates. The new College of European Commissioners, which still has to be approved by the European Parliament, is expected to include just seven women out of 27 member states.

title: Russian paramilitaries from the Bear Brigade leave Burkina Faso
summary: This group of around 100 men, who arrived in Ouagadougou in May, was responsible for protecting several key figures, likely including the junta's leader, Captain Ibrahim Traoré.

title: Harris neither crashes nor shines during first televised interview as candidate
summary: The Democratic candidate had not participated in this exercise since Joe Biden withdrew. On Thursday, in the company of her running mate, Tim Walz, she failed to embody the energy that drives her campaign.

title: Enjoying soy in all its forms
summary: 'Influential Japanese cuisine' (5/6). From edamame to tofu, the legume is as ubiquitous as it is indispensable in Japanese dishes. It reveals a depth of flavor that is yet to win over French taste buds.

title: In Los Angeles, the Château Marmont, refuge for fallen angels
summary: This summer, 'M' passes through the doors of some of film's legendary hotels. In 2010, Sofia Coppola set up her cameras at the Chateau Marmont to shoot 'Somewhere,' a reflection of a certain Hollywood melancholy.

title: Raid by US, Iraqi forces kills 15 ISIS operatives in west Iraq
summary: The operation comes as Baghdad and Washington have been engaged in months of talks over the presence of anti-jihadist coalition forces in Iraq. Despite Iraq's stated goal of a full withdrawal of the forces, no timeline has been made public.

title: Three Scandinavian recipes to prepare this summer
summary: Mouth-watering smørrebrød with smoked eel or blue cheese, potato salad with pickled herring and a sumptuous red fruit dessert.

title: Paris 2024: From amputation to prosthesis, a long road on which research is making progress
summary: Like a number of athletes, several thousand people in France undergo amputations every year. To support them in their reconstruction, scientific innovations have emerged in recent years.

title: Paralympic athlete Fleur Jong, a Dutch long jump superstar
summary: The 28-year-old Dutchwoman will defend her Paralympic long jump title on Saturday.

title: UK's far right is splintered but capable of strong mobilization
summary: While no British far-right movement has managed to break through electorally, this summer's riots demonstrated the strong mobilizing power of far-right networks, and their potential for violence.

title: Oasis fans struggle to get tickets for 2025 reunion tour
summary: Online platforms including Ticketmaster and Gigs and Tours strained under demand from hundreds of thousands of fans trying to bag tickets for Oasis' first tour in 15 years.

title: Marine cloud brightening, a controversial geoengineering technology with potentially harmful effects
summary: An experimental technology that projects marine salt aerosols into the clouds in California was recently challenged in a study that suggests the process could have adverse climatic consequences in other parts of the world.

title: NATO chief backs Ukraine offensive in Russia's Kursk
summary: NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg told Germany's Die Welt that 'Ukraine has a right to defend itself' after the Ukrainian military's incursion into Russia's Kursk region earlier this August.

title: Mexico's President AMLO's judiciary reform bill paralyzes courts
summary: Mexican judges and court staff have been on indefinite strike against the judiciary reform of the outgoing president, who will have a qualified majority in Congress from September 1.
